facts.text: Petition No. 13 of 1962 filed under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for enforcement of Fundamental Rights.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Petition No. 13 of 1962. Petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for the enforc

facts.text: First petitioner is a Company incorporated under the Indian Companies Act with registered office at Calcutta, owner of factory at Varanasi in Uttar Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: The first petitioner, a Company incorporated under the Indian Companys Act with its registered office at Calcutta, is the owner of a factory at Varanasi. in the State of Uttar Pradesh.

facts.text: Petitioners numbers 2 and 3 are shareholders of the first petitioner Company.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners numbers 2 and 3 are the shareholders of the first petitioner Company.

facts.text: State of Uttar Pradesh agreed to advance loan of Rs. 1,45,00,000/- on mortgage of Company's assets at jute mills in Budge Budge and Ghusuri, all in West Bengal.

anchor.surface_text: The State of Uttar Pradesh having agreed to advance a loan of Rs. 1,45,00,000/on the mortgage of the Companys assets at its jute mills it Budge Budge and at Ghusuri, all situated in West Bengal,

facts.text: Deed of mortgage executed at Lucknow in Uttar Pradesh on March 22, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: the deed of mortgage was executed at Lucknow in the State of Uttar Pradesh on March 22, 1957.

facts.text: First petitioner affixed stamps of value Rs. 1,08,751/- purchased from Collector of Stamps, Calcutta to the deed.

anchor.surface_text: To this deed the first petitioner affixed stamps of the value of Rs. 1,08,751/- purchased from the Collector of Stamps, Calcutta.

facts.text: Deed of mortgage registered at Calcutta on April 5, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: It was duly registered at Calcutta on April 5,1957.

facts.text: On March 23, 1957, deed executed between first petitioner and State of Uttar Pradesh releasing part of mortgage property in West Bengal and substituting properties in Uttar Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, on March 23, 1957 by a deed executed between the first petitioner and the State of Uttar Pradesh a part of the mortgage property in West Bengal was released and in its place and stead a part of some properties of Uttar Pradesh were substituted.

facts.text: Deed of substitution duly stamped and registered in Uttar Pradesh; no objection taken to stamps on original deed.

anchor.surface_text: The deed- of substitution was duly stamped and registered in Uttar Pradesh. No objection was then taken to the stamp affixed on the original deed of mortgage.

facts.text: In 1960, first petitioner requested State of Uttar Pradesh to release further part of mortgage properties and substitute with assets of Varanasi factory.

anchor.surface_text: In 1960 the first petitioner made a request to the-state of Uttar Pradesh to release a further part of the mortgage properties included in the original mortgage deed and to accept in their place and stead the assets and properties of the Companys factory at Varanasi as substituted security.

facts.text: Draft deed for substitution sent by first petitioner to Collector of Varanasi for stamp duty assessment.

anchor.surface_text: A draft deed for the substitution was sent by the first petitioner to the Collector of Varanasi for ascertaining the stamp duty payable on it

facts.text: Collector of Varanasi referred matter to Board of Revenue for adjudication of stamp duty.

anchor.surface_text: The Collector referred the matter to the Board of Revenue for adjudication of the Stamp duty on the document for substitution.

facts.text: Board of Revenue, Uttar Pradesh decided original document executed in UP must bear UP Government stamps.

anchor.surface_text: Ultimately, the Board of Revenue, Uttar Pradesh, decided that as the original document had been executed at a place within Uttar Pradesh it must bear stamps issued by the Uttar Pradesh Government.

facts.text: Board rejected argument that document of March 23, 1957 was not an instrument and could bear West Bengal stamps.

anchor.surface_text: It rejected the argument that the document of March 23, 1957 was number an instrument and therefore companyld bear the stamps issued by the West Bengal Government.

facts.text: Board held Company liable to pay Rs. 1,74,000/- as stamp duty on document dated March 23, 1957 before concessional rate.

anchor.surface_text: The Board of Revenue held that the Company was liable to pay, Rs. 1,74,000/- as stamp duty on the document dated March 23, 1957, before it can avail of the companyfessional rate provided for in substituted security.

facts.text: Collector of Varanasi letter dated September 8, 1961 informed draft deed chargeable Rs. 7,554/- provided original mortgage deed stamped with deficit Rs. 1,74,000/-

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, the Collector of Varanasi, by a letter dated September 8, 1961, informed the first petitioner that  a  that the draft deed submitted by it was a substituted security chargeable under Art. 40  c  of Schedule 1-B of the Utttar Pradesh Stamp Amendment Act, 1958, with a duty of Rs. 7,554/-, provided the original mortgage deed of March 22, 1957, was first got properly stamped by payment of deficit duty of Rs. 1,74,000/-.

facts.text: Tehsildar, Chandauli, Varanasi letter dated November 17, 1961 demanding Rs. 1,74,000/- within a week.

anchor.surface_text: This letter- from the Collector was followed by a letter dated November 17, 1961, from the Tehsildar, Chandauli, Varanasi, demanding payment of Rs. 1,74,000/within a week of the receipt of the letter.

facts.text: First petitioner replied to Tehsildar on November 30, 1961 asking for a month's time.

anchor.surface_text: On November 30, the first petitioner replied to this letter asking for a months time.

facts.text: Present petition filed on December 22, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: The present petition was filed on December 22, 1961.

facts.text: Petitioners paid Rs. 1,08,751/- stamp duty in West Bengal after adjudication by Collector of Stamps, Calcutta based on circular dated August 2, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: The order was also challenged as illegal on the ground that the petitioner had already paid stamp duty in West Bengal to the extent of Rs. 1,08,751/- after proper adjudication thereof by the Collector of stamps, Calcutta, based on the provisions of a circular dated August 2, 1954, issued by the State of West Bengal.

facts.text: Original mortgage deed impounded by Inspector of Stamps on August 9, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: It appears from paragraph 19 of the companynter- affidavit filed on behalf of the respondents 2 to 6 that the document in question, i. e., the original mortgage deed dated March 22, 1957, was impounded by the Inspector of Stamps on August 9, 1961.

facts.text: Board of Revenue order dated August 11, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: a writ of certiorari for the quashing of the order of the Board of Revenue dated August 11, 1961

facts.text: Judgment delivered on January 17, 1963 by DAS GUPTA, J.

anchor.surface_text: Sen, M. S. K. Sastri and B. H. Dhebar, for intervener No. 3, 1963. January 17. The judgment of the companyrt was delivered by. DAS GUPTA, J.-

facts.text: Court held that the original mortgage deed was not duly stamped as it did not bear Uttar Pradesh stamps.

anchor.surface_text: The Officers of the State of U. P. therefore rightly held that the original mortgage deed was number duly stamped.

facts.text: Petitioners not entitled to any relief.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners are number, therefore, entitled to any relief.

facts.text: State of West Bengal issued circular dated August 2, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: based on the provisions of a circular dated August 2, 1954, issued by the State of West Bengal.

facts.text: Document impounded on August 9, 1961 as per counter-affidavit of respondents 2 to 6.

anchor.surface_text: It appears from paragraph 19 of the companynter- affidavit filed on behalf of the respondents 2 to 6 that the document in question, i. e., the original mortgage deed dated March 22, 1957, was impounded by the Inspector of Stamps on August 9, 1961.

facts.text: Solicitor General did not press contention against State of West Bengal.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Solicitor-General, who, appeared in support of the petitioner, did number press the companytention against the State of West Bengal.

facts.text: Notices issued to all Advocates-General; several appeared.

anchor.surface_text: In view of the importance of the questions raised, numberices were issued to all the Advocates- General of the States and Advocates, General of several States appeared before us through their Counsel.

issues.text: Where an instrument executed in Uttar Pradesh and consequently liable to stamp duty under the Indian Stamp Act as amended in Uttar Pradesh but relating to property in West Bengal bears stamps overprinted with the name of West Bengal comes before a public officer of Uttar Pradesh, is such officer right in holding that the instrument is not duly stamped inasmuch as it does not bear stamps overprinted with the name of Uttar Pradesh?

anchor.surface_text: Where an instrument executed in Uttar Pradesh and consequently liable to stamp duty under the Indian Stamp Act as amended in Uttar Pradesh but relating to property in West Bengal bears stamps overprinted with the name of West Bengal comes before a public officer of Uttar Pradesh, is such officer right in holding that the instrument is not duly stamped...

issues.text: under the provisions of the Stamp Act a document cannot be said to be unstamped unless it comes within the mischief of s. 15 of the Act and so the Board of Revenue was wrong in holding that the mortgage deed of March 22, 1957, could not be said to be properly stamped unless it bore stamps of the value of Rs. 1,74,000/- issued by the Uttar Pradesh Government

anchor.surface_text: Primarily, the petitioners case is that under the provisions of the Stamp Act a document cannot be said to be unstamped unless it comes within the mischief of s. 15 of the Act and so the Board of Revenue was wrong in holding that the mortgage deed of March 22, 1957, could not be said to be properly stamped...

issues.text: Rule 3 of the Stamp Rules as framed by the Uttar Pradesh Government which provided that stamps overprinted with the words Uttar Pradesh or the letters U.P. was also attacked as unconstitutional on the ground that it constituted an unreasonable restriction on the petitioners fundamental rights under Art. 19(1)(f) and 19(1)(g) of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: Rule 3 of the Stamp Rules as framed by the Uttar Pradesh Government which provided that stamps overprinted with the words Uttar Pradesh or the letters U.P. was also attacked as unconstitutional on the ground that it constituted an unreasonable restriction on the petitioners fundamental rights under Art. 19 1 f and 19 1 f g of the Constitution.

issues.text: the circular of the West Bengal Government dated August 2, 1954 was null and void and the State of West Bengal had illegally exacted the sum of Rs. 1,08,751/- from the petitioner without any authority of law in that behalf and had infringed the fundamental rights of the petitioner under Art. 19(1)(f) and 19(1)(g) of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: Alternatively, it was contended that the circular of the West Bengal Government dated August 2, 1954 was null and void and the State of West Bengal had illegally exacted the sum of Rs. 1,08,751/- from the petitioner without any authority of law in that behalf and had infringed the fundamental rights of the petitioner under Art. 19 1 f and 19 1 g of the Constitution.

issues.text: when it becomes necessary for any public officer of a State ... to decide whether an instrument is or is not duly stamped the law he has to apply is the Indian Stamp Act in the light of the appropriate modifications made by the State Legislature

anchor.surface_text: There cannot be any doubt that when it becomes necessary for any public officer of a State using that word to mean an officer in charge of a public office-to decide whether an instrument is or is not duly stamped the law he has to apply is the Indian Stamp Act in the light of the appropriate modifications made by the State Legislature.

issues.text: whether when the officer found that the stamp had not been affixed or used in accordance with the law for the time being in force in Uttar Pradesh, he was entitled to say also that the stamp had not been affixed or used in accordance with the law for the time being in force in India

anchor.surface_text: Leaving out of consideration for the present, the question of what should be the proper amount of the stamp it is necessary to consider whether when the officer found that the stamp had not been affixed or used in accordance with the law for the time being in force in Uttar Pradesh. he was entitled to say also that the stamp had not been affixed or used in accordance with the law for the time being in force in India.

issues.text: The problem is therefore reduced to this: Where an officer in Uttar Pradesh finds that an instrument has not been stamped in accordance with the law in force in Uttar Pradesh, how is he to proceed?

anchor.surface_text: The problem is therefore reduced to this Where an officer in Uttar Pradesh finds that an instrument has not been stamped in accordance with the law in force in Uttar Pradesh, how is he to proceed ? It is easy to see that similar problems may arise before public officers of other States.

anchor.surface_text: Primarily, the petitioners case is that under the provisions of the Stamp Act a document cannot be said to be unstamped unless it comes within the mischief of s. 15 of the Act and so the Board of Revenue was wrong in holding that the mortgage deed of March 22, 1957, could not be said to be properly stamped

arguments.court_reasoning: Officer applies state-modified Stamp Act including rules; duly stamped requires compliance with UP law as 'law in force in India'

arguments.claim: Public officer must apply Indian Stamp Act as modified by state legislature to determine if duly stamped

anchor.surface_text: There cannot be any doubt that when it becomes necessary for any public officer of a State using that word to mean an officer in charge of a public office-to decide whether an instrument is or is not duly stamped the law he has to apply is the Indian Stamp Act in the light of the appropriate modifications made by the State Legislature.

arguments.claim: s.3 (as amended in UP) creates stamp duty liability on execution in the State (cl. aa)

anchor.surface_text: Section 3 of the Stamp Act creates a liability for stamp duty. Section 3 after its amendment by the U. P. legislature stands thus -- Subject to the provisions of this Act and the exemptions contained in Schedule 1, the following instruments shall be chargeable with duty... aa every instrument mentioned in Schedule I-A or I-B which not having been previously executed by any person was executed in Uttar Pradesh-

arguments.claim: UP Stamp Rule 3 (requiring UP overprinted stamps) has effect of law via ss.74,75,76

anchor.surface_text: While s. 74 empowers the State Government to make rules relating to the sale of stamps, s. 75 empowers the Government generally to make rules to carry out generally the purposes of the Act. Section 76 provides that all rules made under the Act shall be published in the official gazette and on such publication shall have effect as if enacted by the Act. Of the rules framed by the Uttar Pradesh Government it is necessary to consider in the present case Rule 3

arguments.claim: Instrument executed in UP liable under s.3(aa); must use UP overprinted stamps per Rule 3; hence not duly stamped

anchor.surface_text: Rule 3 required that the liability had to be discharged by using stamps overprinted with the words Uttar Pradesh or U. P The instrument did in fact bear stamps overprinted with the words West Bengal and not with the words Uttar Pradesh or U. P The public officer was therefore bound to hold that it had not been stamped in accordance with the law in force in Uttar Pradesh.

arguments.claim: 'Duly stamped' under s.2(11) requires stamp affixed/used per law in force in India; UP officer finds non-compliance with UP law = non-compliance with India law

anchor.surface_text: Leaving out of consideration for the present, the question of what should be the proper amount of the stamp it is necessary to consider whether when the officer found that the stamp had not been affixed or used in accordance with the law for the time being in force in Uttar Pradesh. he was entitled to say also that the stamp had not been affixed or used in accordance with the law for the time being in force in India.

arguments.claim: State amendments treat the State as equivalent to 'India' for stamp duty liability

anchor.surface_text: In amending to Stamp Act what the State legislatures substantially did was to treat the particular State as equivalent to India. Thus, after the amendment by the U.P. legislature the position in law is that execution of an instrument in Uttar Pradesh is made the primary dutiable event and liability to stamp duty arises on such execution.

arguments.claim: Liability arising in particular State must be discharged per that State's law (Act + Rules)

anchor.surface_text: It stands to reason that liability having arisen in a particular State it cannot be held to be discharged in accordance with the law in force in India unless it is discharged in accordance with the law of the State where it arises.

arguments.claim: For instruments with dual liability (execution in one state, receipt in another), s.19A requires only excess duty in second state with its stamps if higher

anchor.surface_text: Section 19-A in terms applies only to an instrument which after becoming chargeable in any State outside Uttar Pradesh becomes chargeable in Uttar Pradesh with a higher rate of duty... only the excess has to be paid in Uttar Pradesh and it is only this excess which requires to be paid in Uttar Pradesh stamps.

arguments.claim: Extends s.19A logic: if second state rate same/lower, no further duty

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us, however, that where the rate of duty in Uttar Pradesh is the same or even lower, no further duty is payable on such an instrument. For, it would be anomalous and unreasonable to hold that the legislature intended...

arguments.claim: Here, execution in UP (primary event) requires UP stamps; WB stamping irrelevant for UP officers

anchor.surface_text: The Officers of the State of U. P. therefore rightly held that the original mortgage deed was not duly stamped.

arguments.claim: Petitioners not entitled to any relief

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners are not, therefore, entitled to any relief.

holdings.text: Public officer of a State must apply the Indian Stamp Act in the light of the appropriate modifications made by the State Legislature to decide whether an instrument is duly stamped.

anchor.surface_text: There cannot be any doubt that when it becomes necessary for any public officer of a State using that word to mean an officer in charge of a public office-to decide whether an instrument is or is not duly stamped the law he has to apply is the Indian Stamp Act in the light of the appropriate modifications made by the State Legislature.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct textual application of federal structure where states amend central act; officer bound by state version.

holdings.text: An instrument executed in Uttar Pradesh is chargeable with duty under Section 3(aa) as amended in Uttar Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: The document had been executed in Uttar Pradesh. So, it became liable to pay duty under s. 3  aa  of the Act as amended in Uttar Pradesh.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Execution in state triggers liability per state-amended s.3(aa); primary dutiable event is execution.

holdings.text: Rule 3 of Uttar Pradesh Stamp Rules requires duties to be paid by impressed or adhesive stamps overprinted with 'Uttar Pradesh' or 'U.P.' and has effect as if enacted in the Act via Sections 74, 75, 76.

anchor.surface_text: While s. 74 empowers the State Government to make rules relating to the sale of stamps, s. 75 empowers the Government generally to make rules to carry out generally the purposes of the Act. Section 76 provides that all rules made under the Act shall be published in the official gazette and on such publication shall have effect as if enacted by the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rules published under s.76 have statutory force; Rule 3 specifies stamp type for compliance.

holdings.text: The mortgage deed bearing West Bengal overprinted stamps was not stamped in accordance with the law in force in Uttar Pradesh as required by Rule 3.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 3 required that the liability had to be discharged by using stamps overprinted with the words Uttar Pradesh or U. P The instrument did in fact bear stamps overprinted with the words West Bengal and not with the words Uttar Pradesh or U. P The public officer was therefore bound to hold that it had not been stamped in accordance with the law in force in Uttar Pradesh.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applied s.3(aa) and Rule 3 to facts: execution in UP requires UP stamps; WB stamps non-compliant.

holdings.text: Non-compliance with the law in force in Uttar Pradesh means the stamp has not been affixed or used in accordance with the law for the time being in force in India under Section 2(11).

anchor.surface_text: Leaving out of consideration for the present, the question of what should be the proper amount of the stamp it is necessary to consider whether when the officer found that the stamp had not been affixed or used in accordance with the law for the time being in force in Uttar Pradesh. he was entitled to say also that the stamp had not been affixed or used in accordance with the law for the time being in force in India.

holdings.reasoning_summary: State amendments equate state to 'India'; s.2(11) definition incorporates state law compliance.

holdings.text: State legislatures amended Stamp Act to treat the particular State as equivalent to India for stamp duty liability on execution.

anchor.surface_text: In amending to Stamp Act what the State legislatures substantially did was to treat the particular State as equivalent to India. Thus, after the amendment by the U.P. legislature the position in law is that execution of an instrument in Uttar Pradesh is made the primary dutiable event and liability to stamp duty arises on such execution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Purposive interpretation of amendments: shifts dutiable event from 'India' to 'State'.

holdings.text: Liability to stamp duty having arisen in a particular State must be discharged in accordance with the law of that State.

anchor.surface_text: It stands to reason that liability having arisen in a particular State it cannot be held to be discharged in accordance with the law in force in India unless it is discharged in accordance with the law of the State where it arises.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Logical necessity: state-specific discharge for state-arisen liability.

holdings.text: Uttar Pradesh officers rightly held that the original mortgage deed was not duly stamped.

anchor.surface_text: The Officers of the State of U. P. therefore rightly held that the original mortgage deed was number duly stamped.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of above principles to facts: execution in UP requires UP stamps under state law.

holdings.text: Where an instrument becomes chargeable in one state then in another with same or lower rate, no further duty payable.

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us, however, that where the rate of duty in Uttar Pradesh is the same or even lower, no further duty is payable on such an instrument. For, it would be anomalous and unreasonable to hold that the legislature intended...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Extension of s.19A logic by analogy to avoid anomaly; purposive.

holdings.text: The petitioners are not entitled to any relief.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners are number, therefore, entitled to any relief.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Dismissal follows from holdings on stamping compliance.

anchor.surface_text: The Officers of the State of U. P. therefore rightly held that the original mortgage deed was number duly stamped. The petitioners are number, therefore, entitled to any relief.

outcome.relief_summary: Petitioners not entitled to any relief; mortgage deed held not duly stamped under Uttar Pradesh Stamp Act and Rules

anchor.surface_text: There cannot be any doubt that when it becomes necessary for any public officer of a State using that word to mean an officer in charge of a public office-to decide whether an instrument is or is not duly stamped the law he has to apply is the Indian Stamp Act in the light of the appropriate modifications made by the State Legislature.
The Officers of the State of U. P. therefore rightly held that the original mortgage deed was number duly stamped. The petitioners are number, therefore, entitled to any relief.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 3 required that the liability had to be discharged by using stamps overprinted with the words Uttar Pradesh or U. P The instrument did in fact bear stamps overprinted with the words West Bengal and not with the words Uttar Pradesh or U. P The public officer was therefore bound to hold that it had not been stamped in accordance with the law in force in Uttar Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: Leaving out of consideration for the present, the question of what should be the proper amount of the stamp it is necessary to consider whether when the officer found that the stamp had not been affixed or used in accordance with the law for the time being in force in Uttar Pradesh. he was entitled to say also that the stamp had not been affixed or used in accordance with the law for the time being in force in India.
The Officers of the State of U. P. therefore rightly held that the original mortgage deed was number duly stamped. The petitioners are number, therefore, entitled to any relief.

edges.explanation: Holding on amendments treating state as India supports holding on discharging liability per state law

anchor.surface_text: In amending to Stamp Act what the State legislatures substantially did was to treat the particular State as equivalent to India. Thus, after the amendment by the U.P. legislature the position in law is that execution of an instrument in Uttar Pradesh is made the primary dutiable event and liability to stamp duty arises on such execution.
The Officers of the State of U. P. therefore rightly held that the original mortgage deed was number duly stamped. The petitioners are number, therefore, entitled to any relief.

edges.explanation: Liability arising in state discharged per that state's law (h7) supports deed not stamped per UP Rule 3 (h4).

anchor.surface_text: It stands to reason that liability having arisen in a particular State it cannot be held to be discharged in accordance with the law in force in India unless it is discharged in accordance with the law of the State where it arises.
The Officers of the State of U. P. therefore rightly held that the original mortgage deed was number duly stamped. The petitioners are number, therefore, entitled to any relief.
